title: 114_hr6255
content: The Act may be cited as the "Norman Yoshio Mineta Congressional Gold Medal Act". Norman Yoshio Mineta was born in 1931 in San Jose, California to immigrant parents from Japan. During World War II, his family was relocated to an internment camp. After serving in the US Army, Mineta joined his father's insurance business in San Jose's Japantown. Norman Mineta was appointed to the San Jose Housing Authority in 1966 and became a city councilmember a year later. He was elected as the first Asian American mayor of a major US city in 1971, focusing on economic development and community relations. From 1975 to 1995, he served as a Member of the U.S. House of Representatives. Norman Mineta served as a Member of the U.S. House of Representatives, representing Santa Clara County and Silicon Valley. He was involved in various committees, including Budget, Intelligence, and Science. In 1978, he introduced a bipartisan resolution to establish "Asian/Pacific American Heritage Week" in May to commemorate the arrival of Japanese immigrants and the completion of the transcontinental railroad by Chinese laborers. In 1987, Norman Mineta signed the Civil Liberties Act, offering an official apology and redress for injustices against Americans of Japanese ancestry during World War II. President Ronald Reagan later signed the bill into law in 1988. Mineta advocated for transportation laws to improve air travel safety and accessibility for Americans with disabilities during his time in the House of Representatives. Norman Mineta co-founded the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus and the Asian Pacific American Institute for Congressional Studies in 1994. In 2000, he became the first Asian American to serve in a Presidential Cabinet as the Secretary of Commerce under President Clinton. In 2001, he continued his dedication to public service by serving as Secretary of Transportation under President George W. Bush. Norman Y. Mineta served as Secretary of Transportation under President George W. Bush. He implemented critical reforms in transportation and security networks after the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. The San Jose City Council renamed the city's airport to honor him, and he received the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2006. Norman Yoshio Mineta, who served as Secretary of Transportation under President George W. Bush, has dedicated his life to public service and his community. He experienced internment as a child but has shown exemplary dignity and integrity in his work. He received the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2006, and the San Jose City Council renamed the city's airport in his honor. Norman Yoshio Mineta will be presented with a Congressional Gold Medal for his dedication to public service, civic engagement, and civil rights. The gold medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals will be made available. The Secretary has the authority to create and sell bronze duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering all costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under specific codes.
